Colin,
Have you ever taken a look at Grammatical Evolution
(http://www.grammatical-evolution.org/)

From what I understand about it, GE tries to solve
that problem of separating the genotype from the
phenotype.

-- Rog



--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> With regard to the speciation debate I would like to
> summarise just to 
> make things clearer and perhaps to add a few extra
> points  - for my own 
> benefit if nothing else...
> 
> - Genotypes are combined not phenotypes. Sort of
> obvious huh.
> - Biological organisms have no way of assessing
> genetic compatibility 
> directly and therefore use phenotype as an indirect
> way of assessing 
> this compatibility. After all, similar genotypes
> will normally result in 
> similar phenotypes.
> 
> A few points here:
> 1) I think I've made this point before - we have a
> very limited amout of 
> computational power to hand when compared to nature.
> Therefore if we can 
> make shortcuts then we should do so. So, because we
> have direct access 
> to the genomes we should then compare them directly
> if it makes sense to 
> do so. There is no point simulating systems that
> came about to solve a 
> problem that we (within simulations) do not have.
> 
> 2) As has been pointed out, nature's technique is by
> no means perfect. 
> Consider predators that mimick some part of a prey's
> phenotype in order 
> to pretend to be a potential mate, thus luring them
> into eating range 
> :)  This can be a familiar (sexy) shape or the
> emitting of a pheromone, 
> etc.  If nature had direct access to genomes then
> the poor old prey 
> would be able to determine that the potential mate
> over there is in fact 
> a predator, and to 'leg it'(as we say in the UK)
> poste haste!
> 
>  
> So is this the full story? Does phenotype comparison
> have /any/ possible 
> use within simulations? Or is it the case that the
> the only useful role 
> of phenotype is in it's expression within an
> environment so that we can 
> assess its fitness? I think it does have a use...
> 
> Consider an indirect encoding under which a very
> small mutation DID give 
> rise to a significant and beneficial change in the
> phenotype. We now 
> have organisms that have almost identical genotype
> but a significantly 
> different phenotype. For comic potential let's say
> this creature grew an 
> extra eye on the back of it's head, and that this
> was quite good for 
> spotting oncoming predators. In nature it is quite
> possible that 
> creatures without this mutation (and perhaps even
> those with it) would 
> see the 'mutants' as being less desirable mates,
> because they do not 
> meet the criteria for a good mate based upon what
> they know. This could 
> actually be one way in which new species arise. The
> mutants, rejected by 
> what they consider to be good mates, now mate with
> the next best 
> thing... another mutant. Thus a rudamentary form of
> speciation has come 
> about.
> 
> If we were comparing genotypes then this speciation
> never would have 
> occured. Was the speciation in this example actually
> useful? I think it 
> was because it effectively focused a new
> evolutionary search around the 
> mutation by forcing mutants to mate with each other.
> If the mutants 
> continued to mate with non-mutatnts as normal then
> the mutation would 
> still become dominant eventually through selection -
> but this would have 
> occured at a slower rate.
> 
> So I recon phenotype comparison can be useful over
> and above plain 
> genome comparison. It's a bit of a concocted
> scenario but there it is.
> 
> Whether this is of any use within simulations is, I
> suspect,  yet 
> another question for research. As Derek and Mitchell
> were (sort of) 
> saying earlier, we need to pick-and-choose
> techniques employed by the 
> biological world in order to obtain a balance
> between simplicity and 
> efficacy with the limited computational resources we
> have to hand.
> 
> Colin.
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
